did.unittitle: Alex N. Kniazeff (Aleksei Nikolaevich Kniazev) papers

physdesc.extent: 43 manuscript boxes, 2 oversize boxes, 17 microfilm reels

did.abstract: Correspondence, minutes, financial records, bulletins, personal documents, printed matter, and photographs, relating to the Russian Boy Scouts movement abroad and to Russian émigré affairs. In part, microfilm.

userestrict.head: Publication Rights
userestrict.p: For copyright status, please contact the Hoover Institution Archives.

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation
prefercite.p: [Identification of item], Alex N. Kniazeff Papers, [Box no.], Hoover Institution Archives.

altformavail.head: Location of Originals
altformavail.p: In part, originals in: Museum of Russian Culture, San Francisco.

bioghist.head: Biography
bioghist.p: Born at Tsitsikhar station on the Chinese Eastern Railway on 5 August 1909, where his father, an army engineer officer, was stationed, Kniazev spent the first half of his life in China. As his father was transferred to Manchuria station, where he was commandant during the Russian Civil War, and later to Harbin, where he was assistant commandant, A. N. Kniazeff moved with him, graduating from American Methodist College in Harbin in 1927. From 1927 to 1933 he was a student at Harbin Polytechnic Institute, receiving his baccalaureate degree in electrical and mechanical engineering. Simultaneously, he completed a training course at the Russkii Obshchevoinskii soiuz military academy in 1934.

Following his graduation, he moved to Tientsin, where he worked as an engineer for a number of companies until 1945, when he was forced to escape to Shanghai. He was interned at Tubabao refugee camp until January 1951, when he finally arrived in San Francisco. From 1952 to 1955 he was an instructor at the Army Language School in Monterey until he was able to secure employment closer to his field of specialization, first as an instrumentation designer for Bechtel Corporation (1955-1958), and then at Pacific Gas and Electric Company until retirement (1958-1974).

As a member of the Russian boy scouts since 1922 in Harbin, he rose to become Chief Russian Scout of St. George's Knights (Natsional'naia organizatsiia russkikh skautov). Kniazeff died in San Francisco in 1993.

chronitem.event: Degree, Electrical and Mechanical Engineering, Harbin Polytechnic Institute, Harbin, China

eventgrp.event: Engineering and administrative positions, Kailan Mining Administration, Tientsin, China

chronitem.event: General Consulting Engineer, International Refugee Organization, Tubabao, Samar, Philippines
Instructor of Russian, U. S. Army Language School, Monterey, California
Instrumentation Designer, Bechtel Corporation, San Francisco, California
Senior Draftsman, Pacific Gas and Electric Company, San Francisco, California
Scoutmaster, Natsional'naia organizatsiia rossiiskikh skautov (St. George's Knights)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Note
scopecontent.p: This collection consists of correspondence, clippings and other matter reflecting Kniazeff's involvement in various émigré organizations. He was a member of the San Francisco Trans-Baikal Cossacks' Stanitza and of the Harbin Polytechnic Alumni Association, and senior scoutmaster of the Natsional'naia Organizatsiia Russkikh Skautov (National Organization of Russian Scouts, or St. George's Knights, as it was incorporated in California). Most of the collection relates to the history of the Russian Boy Scout movement abroad, particularly for the period 1963-1975.

Detailed processing and preservation microfilming for these materials were made possible by a generous grant from the National Endowment for the Humanities and by matching funds from the Hoover Institution and the Museum of Russian Culture. The grant also provides depositing a microfilm copy in the Hoover Institution Archives. The original materials remain in the Museum of Russian Culture, San Francisco, as its property. A transfer table indicating corresponding box and reel numbers is available at the Hoover Institution Archives.

The Hoover Institution assumes all responsibility for notifying users that they must comply with the copyright law of the United States (Title 17 United States Code) and Hoover Rules for the Use and Reproduction of Archival Materials.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Includes family documents and illustrated manuscript by Kniazeff's father on carpentry, as well as personal, employment and army reserve files on Kniazeff's career, arranged alphabetically by subject

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Arranged chronologically by correspondent

did.unittitle: Natsional'naia Organizatsiia Russkikh Skautov (St. George's Knights, Inc.),

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Consists of correspondence, orders, minutes, publications and other materials, arranged alphabetically by physical form

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Consists mainly of materials relating to the organizations Kniazeff was involved in, arranged alphabetically by name of organization, and therein by physical form

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Includes calendars, clippings, leaflets, programs and issues of periodicals, arranged alphabetically by physical form

scopecontent.p: Includes awards, certificates, commendations, diploma and other documents relating to Kniazeff's education, employment and social activities

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Clippings, correspondence, financial statements, reports, printed matter and other materials relating to this organization's activities

did.unittitle: CORO Corporation (Consolidated Real Estate Opportunities Corporation).

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Consists of incoming and outgoing correspondence, financial statements, annual and semi-annual reports and other materials

did.unittitle: Kharbinskii Politekhnicheskii Institut (Harbin Polytechnic Institute). Primarily composed of documents relating to the activities of its alumni association.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Includes clippings of reminiscences and other related matter

did.unittitle: Obshche-kazachii soiuz v g. San Frantsisko (All Cossack's Union of San Francisco).

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Includes material pertaining to other Cossack organizations

scopecontent.p: Includes Kazachii klich, #1 (March 1954) and Kazak, #176-192 (1963-1964, incomplete)

did.unittitle: Russian Community Club, Inc., San Mateo, California (Russkii Obshchestvennyi Klub)
Russkaia Pravoslavnaia Tserkov' (Orthodox Eastern Church, Russian).

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Includes award presented by Archbishop Viktor of China to G. M. Ivanov, 1940 October 12

did.unittitle: Society of Russian Veterans, San Francisco (Obshchestvo russkikh veteranov Velikoi voiny).

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Includes typed draft of B. B. Filimonov's "Bor'ba v Zaural'e," 1935, published serially in the Society's journal, Viestnik Obshchestva veteranov Velikoi voiny, correspondence relating to its publication and author, and other materials for publication in the journal, as well as documents relating to the organization's other activities

did.unittitle: Trans-Baikal Cossacks' Stanitza of San Francisco

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Includes issues of Nash vestnik (Tubabao), 1951 and Kharbinskoe vremia, #17 (1941)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Includes holiday issues of Russkaia zhizn', 1964-1969

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Mostly from San Francisco in the 1950s-1960s, but some from Russia, 1917 and possibly earlier - musical evenings, balls and school productions
